content.title: Hypothyroidism
content.summary: Clinical syndrome of thyroid hormone deficiency characterized by slowed metabolism affecting virtually all organ systems, most commonly caused by Hashimoto's thyroiditis in iodine-sufficient areas
key_points: Primary hypothyroidism (95%) due to thyroid gland failure; elevated TSH, low T4
Secondary/central hypothyroidism (5%) due to pituitary or hypothalamic disease; low/normal TSH, low T4
Hashimoto's thyroiditis is most common cause in iodine-sufficient regions
Classic symptoms: fatigue, cold intolerance, weight gain, constipation, dry skin, bradycardia
Levothyroxine is treatment of choice; full replacement dose 1.6 mcg/kg/day
Monitor TSH 6-8 weeks after dose changes; target TSH 0.5-2.5 mU/L
Myxedema coma is life-threatening severe hypothyroidism requiring IV T4 and supportive care
content.statement: Hypothyroidism is a clinical syndrome resulting from deficiency of thyroid hormones, causing widespread slowing of metabolic processes and affecting virtually all organ systems, requiring lifelong thyroid hormone replacement therapy.

explanation.intuition: Thyroid hormone is the body's metabolic thermostat. When deficient, everything slows down - heart rate, gut motility, reflexes, mental processing, and heat production. Patients literally 'run cold' physically and metabolically.
explanation.key_insight: Diagnosing hypothyroidism requires understanding the hypothalamic-pituitary-thyroid axis. In primary hypothyroidism, the failing thyroid cannot respond to TSH, so TSH rises in attempt to stimulate more hormone. In central hypothyroidism, the problem is insufficient TSH production.
explanation.technical_details: Thyroid hormones (T3, T4) regulate basal metabolic rate, thermogenesis, protein synthesis, and tissue differentiation. T4 is the predominant circulating hormone, converted to active T3 in peripheral tissues by deiodinases. Autoimmune destruction (Hashimoto's) involves anti-TPO and anti-thyroglobulin antibodies with lymphocytic infiltration and gradual thyroid failure.

definitions_glossary.primary_hypothyroidism: Thyroid hormone deficiency due to thyroid gland failure, characterized by elevated TSH
definitions_glossary.secondary_hypothyroidism: Thyroid hormone deficiency due to pituitary TSH deficiency
definitions_glossary.tertiary_hypothyroidism: Thyroid hormone deficiency due to hypothalamic TRH deficiency
definitions_glossary.hashimotos_thyroiditis: Autoimmune thyroiditis with anti-TPO antibodies; most common cause of hypothyroidism
definitions_glossary.tsh: Thyroid-stimulating hormone produced by anterior pituitary; primary screening test
definitions_glossary.free_t4: Unbound, active thyroxine; measured to confirm hypothyroidism
definitions_glossary.anti_tpo_antibodies: Antibodies against thyroid peroxidase; marker of autoimmune thyroiditis
definitions_glossary.levothyroxine: Synthetic T4; treatment of choice for hypothyroidism
definitions_glossary.myxedema: Severe hypothyroidism with characteristic non-pitting edema from mucopolysaccharide deposition
definitions_glossary.myxedema_coma: Life-threatening decompensated hypothyroidism with altered mental status and hypothermia
definitions_glossary.subclinical_hypothyroidism: Elevated TSH with normal free T4; may progress to overt disease
definitions_glossary.sick_euthyroid_syndrome: Altered thyroid function tests due to non-thyroidal illness; avoid treatment

pathophysiology.mechanism: Deficiency of thyroid hormones (T3, T4) leading to decreased basal metabolic rate and slowed function of virtually all organ systems

primary_hypothyroidism: Hashimoto's thyroiditis (autoimmune) - most common in iodine-sufficient areas

systemic_effects.cardiovascular: Bradycardia, diastolic hypertension, pericardial effusion, elevated LDL
systemic_effects.neurologic: Delayed relaxation phase of reflexes, carpal tunnel syndrome, depression, cognitive slowing
systemic_effects.dermatologic: Dry skin, coarse hair, hair loss, myxedema
systemic_effects.metabolic: Weight gain, cold intolerance, hyponatremia, hyperlipidemia

laboratory_criteria.primary_hypothyroidism: TSH elevated (>4.5-10 mU/L), Free T4 low
laboratory_criteria.subclinical_hypothyroidism: TSH mildly elevated (4.5-10 mU/L), Free T4 normal
laboratory_criteria.central_hypothyroidism: TSH low or inappropriately normal, Free T4 low
laboratory_criteria.additional_testing: Anti-TPO antibodies (confirms autoimmune etiology), lipid panel, CBC

diagnostic_criteria.severity_assessment: Severe if TSH >50 mU/L, Free T4 significantly low, or symptomatic with myxedema features

levothyroxine_therapy.formulation: Synthetic L-thyroxine (T4); brand vs generic considerations

dosing.full_replacement: 1.6 mcg/kg ideal body weight/day for complete athyreotic patients
dosing.initial_dose_elderly_cad: Start 12.5-25 mcg/day, increase by 12.5-25 mcg every 4-6 weeks
dosing.subclinical: Consider treatment if TSH >10 mU/L or symptoms present

levothyroxine_therapy.administration: Take on empty stomach 30-60 minutes before breakfast; consistent timing

monitoring.timing: Check TSH 6-8 weeks after dose change
monitoring.target: TSH 0.5-2.5 mU/L for most adults; higher (1-5 mU/L) acceptable in elderly
monitoring.frequency: Annual TSH once stable; more frequent if dose changes or symptoms

special_considerations.pregnancy: Increase dose by 30% when pregnancy confirmed; monthly TSH monitoring
special_considerations.myxedema_coma: IV levothyroxine 200-400 mcg loading dose, hydrocortisone, supportive care
special_considerations.malabsorption: Consider IV or softgel formulations; separate from calcium, iron, PPI

skos.definition: A clinical syndrome of thyroid hormone deficiency causing slowed metabolism and affecting virtually all organ systems, requiring lifelong hormone replacement

learning_objectives: Recognize clinical manifestations of hypothyroidism across organ systems
Interpret thyroid function tests (TSH, Free T4) for diagnosis
Initiate and adjust levothyroxine therapy appropriately
Identify patients requiring special considerations (elderly, CAD, pregnancy)
Recognize and manage myxedema coma as a medical emergency
clinical_pearls: TSH is the single best screening test for primary hypothyroidism
Always check TSH and Free T4 together if central hypothyroidism is suspected
Start low and go slow in elderly patients and those with coronary artery disease
Delayed relaxation phase of deep tendon reflexes is pathognomonic
Anti-TPO antibodies positive in >90% of Hashimoto's thyroiditis
Pregnancy increases levothyroxine requirements by 30-50%; check TSH monthly
Take levothyroxine consistently on empty stomach; separate from calcium, iron
Don't treat sick euthyroid syndrome - thyroid function normalizes with recovery
